pr_title: Allow to use camel case environment name

timeline.bodyText: I don't understand this. How is that effected that both hyphenated and CamelCase are accepted?
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: I guess this comes from the fact that CaseFormat.UPPER_CAMEL.to(CaseFormat.LOWER_HYPHEN, name); is identity on name which is already LOWER_HYPHEN.
replies.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: Naaa - I do not get it too :/
replies.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: Can we make the code less "clever" or more documented?
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
I will do unit tests for that.
name() makes formatting uniformed

ala becomes ala
Ala becomes ala
DuzAla becomes duza-ala
duza-ala becomes duza-ala
Duz-Ala becomes duza-ala
replies.author: kokosing

replies.bodyText:
name() makes formatting uniformed

-> canonicalName  + javadoc?
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
Duz-Ala becomes duza-ala

My bad Duz-Ala becomes duz--ala
replies.author: kokosing

replies.bodyText:
canonicalName

I don't think it needs a javadoc
replies.author: kokosing

timeline.bodyText: don't think it's desired so add a comment it's incidental
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: I fixed that case with regex.
replies.author: kokosing

timeline.bodyText:
/**
 * Converts camel case name to hyphenated. Returns input if the name is already hyphenated.
 */

-- the javadoc is important, as we do not commit ourselves to supporting anything beyond lowercase hyphenaed and CamelCase forms, and we should capture somewhere.
timeline.author: findepi

timeline.message:
Allow to use camel case environment name

This is useful when you want to simply copy an environment class name.

Allow to use camel case environment name

This is useful when you want to simply copy an environment class name.
